explanations.summary: CO = SV × HR. Increased by: increased preload (Starling), decreased afterload. NOT increased by: decreased preload, increased afterload, increased BP (which increases afterload). Preload↑ = CO↑; Afterload↑ = CO↓.

whyCorrect.b: Decreased preload (reduced venous return) DECREASES stroke volume via Frank-Starling mechanism, thus DECREASING cardiac output.
whyCorrect.c: Increased afterload (increased arterial resistance) makes ejection harder, DECREASING stroke volume and cardiac output.
whyCorrect.e: Increased blood pressure increases afterload, which DECREASES cardiac output (heart must work against higher pressure).

whyIncorrect.a: Increased preload INCREASES cardiac output via Frank-Starling mechanism (more stretch = stronger contraction = larger SV).
whyIncorrect.d: Decreased afterload INCREASES cardiac output (easier to eject blood = larger SV).

explanations.summary: Beat-by-beat matching of stroke volume to venous return is the FRANK-STARLING MECHANISM - an intrinsic cardiac property. More filling → more stretch → stronger contraction → larger SV. No nerves required.

whyCorrect.e: Frank-Starling mechanism: Increased venous return stretches ventricle → optimizes actin-myosin overlap → stronger contraction → SV matches venous return. This is INTRINSIC (no nerves needed), works beat-by-beat.

whyIncorrect.a: Vagal negative inotropy REDUCES contractility - doesn't match SV to venous return.
whyIncorrect.b: Sympathetic positive inotropy increases contractility but is NOT the beat-by-beat matching mechanism - it's extrinsic regulation.
whyIncorrect.c: Dromotropic effects affect conduction velocity, not stroke volume matching.
whyIncorrect.d: Extracardiac mechanisms (like baroreflexes) are slower responses, not beat-by-beat intrinsic matching.

explanations.summary: Frank-Starling mechanism provides beat-by-beat matching of left and right ventricular output to venous return. Intrinsic mechanism based on length-tension relationship - no neural input required.

whyCorrect.d: Frank-Starling mechanism: Increased end-diastolic volume stretches myocytes → increased force of contraction → stroke volume automatically matches venous return. This ensures L and R ventricles pump equal volumes.

whyIncorrect.a: Sympathetic positive inotropy is extrinsic regulation for exercise/stress - not the intrinsic beat-by-beat matching.
whyIncorrect.b: Vagal negative inotropy reduces contractility - opposite of what's needed for matching.
whyIncorrect.c: Extracardiac mechanisms are slower regulatory responses (seconds to minutes), not instantaneous beat-by-beat matching.
whyIncorrect.e: Dromotropic effects affect AV conduction, not ventricular stroke volume.
